PA_Relevance: Overuse supports MOH diagnosis (G44.41); document frequency ≥15 days/month x 3 months
Notes: Most common OTC; hepatotoxicity risk at high doses

PA_Relevance: Overuse supports MOH diagnosis; GI/renal risks with chronic use
Notes: Available OTC up to 200mg tablets

PA_Relevance: Longer half-life than ibuprofen; less frequent dosing
Notes: 220mg OTC = 200mg naproxen base

PA_Relevance: Overuse supports MOH; also antiplatelet effects
Notes: Low-dose (81mg) for cardiac not counted for headache

PA_Relevance: ⚠️ LOWER THRESHOLD: ≥10 days/month = MOH. Caffeine component increases dependence risk
Notes: Excedrin Migraine is identical formulation; FDA-approved for migraine

PA_Relevance: Lower threshold than simple analgesics; caffeine withdrawal contributes to rebound
Notes: No aspirin - for patients with ASA sensitivity

PA_Relevance: High aspirin dose; rapid absorption powder form; popular in Southeast US
Notes: Regional popularity; powder formulation

PA_Relevance: Similar to Excedrin but powder; regional popularity
Notes: Powder formulation for faster onset

PA_Relevance: Lower caffeine than Excedrin; aspirin-based
Notes: Older brand; still available

PA_Relevance: Lower doses of each ingredient; buffered
Notes: Contains buffers for GI tolerance

PA_Relevance: Caffeine alone counts toward combination threshold when used for headache; withdrawal triggers MOH
Notes: Often used as migraine adjuvant; withdrawal headache common

PA_Relevance: FDA-approved for migraine; faster absorption than tablets; still simple analgesic threshold
Notes: Solubilized = faster onset; same MOH threshold as regular ibuprofen

PA_Relevance: Identical to regular ibuprofen; marketing differentiation only
Notes: Same as regular Motrin; FDA migraine indication

PA_Relevance: No caffeine = simple analgesic threshold; dual MOA
Notes: Newer combination; no caffeine so 15-day threshold applies

PA_Relevance: Contains caffeine = 10-day threshold; antihistamine adds sedation
Notes: Marketed for menstrual but used for headache; caffeine = lower MOH threshold

PA_Relevance: Essentially Excedrin equivalent; marketed for menstrual pain
Notes: Same formulation as Excedrin

PA_Relevance: Effervescent = faster absorption; high sodium content
Notes: High sodium - caution in HTN; no caffeine = 15-day threshold

PA_Relevance: Naproxen component counts for MOH tracking; diphenhydramine for sleep
Notes: Nighttime formulation; track naproxen days

PA_Relevance: Ibuprofen component counts for MOH tracking
Notes: Nighttime formulation

PA_Relevance: Acetaminophen component counts for MOH tracking
Notes: Nighttime formulation

PA_Relevance: Not a headache treatment but sometimes used; does not count toward MOH
Notes: May be used for migraine-associated nausea; sedating

PA_Relevance: Used for migraine-associated nausea/vertigo; does not count toward analgesic MOH
Notes: Contains diphenhydramine derivative

PA_Relevance: Salicylate component minimal for headache; used for GI symptoms
Notes: Not typically used for headache pain

PA_Relevance: Evidence-based migraine preventive (Level B); 400-600mg daily; does NOT cause MOH
Notes: Preventive not acute; diarrhea with oxide form

PA_Relevance: Evidence-based migraine preventive (Level B); 400mg daily; does NOT cause MOH
Notes: Preventive; causes fluorescent urine (harmless)

PA_Relevance: Evidence-based migraine preventive (Level C); 100-300mg daily; does NOT cause MOH
Notes: Preventive; may take 3 months for effect

PA_Relevance: Mixed evidence for migraine prevention; does NOT cause MOH
Notes: Herbal; inconsistent standardization

PA_Relevance: ⚠️ WITHDRAWN from US market (hepatotoxicity); Level A evidence but safety concerns
Notes: No longer available in US; was effective but unsafe
